hints_html: We can consider \(x\) as a constant inside the integral
hints_latex: We can consider $x$ as a constant inside the integral
hints_raw: We can consider <math> x </math> as a constant inside the integral
sols_html:
First we solve the integral considering \(x\) as a constant:

\[\begin{aligned} g(x)&=\int_0^1(xe^t-t)^2dt\\ &=\int_0^1(x^2e^{2t}-2xe^tt+t^2)dt\\ &=x^2\int_0^1e^{2t}dt-2x\int_0^1e^ttdt+\int_0^1t^2dt\end{aligned}\]

The first integral in the sum is

\(\int_0^1e^{2t}dt=\frac{1}{2}(e^2-e^0)=\frac{1}{2}(e^2-1)\)

Now we solve \(\int_0^1e^ttdt\) by parts letting \(u=t\) and \(dv=e^tdt\) so that \(du=dt\) and \(v=e^t\). Hence

\[\begin{aligned} \int_0^1e^ttdt&=te^t\big|_0^1-\int_0^1e^tdt\\ &=(e-0)-(e-1)=1\end{aligned}\]

The last integral in the sum is:

\(\int_0^1t^2dt=\frac{1}{3}(1^3-0^3)=\frac{1}{3}\)

So

\(g(x)=\frac{x^2}{2}(e^2-1)-2x+\frac{1}{3}\)

The derivative is directly computed to be:

\(g'(x)=x(e^2-1)-2\)

Which is zero at \(x=\frac{2}{e^2-1}\).

To make sure it is a minimum we use the second derivative test. The second derivative is:

\(g''(x)=e^2-1\)

Which is always positive (Remember that \(e>2\)). This means \(x=\frac{2}{e^2-1}\) is the minimum for \(g\). Plugging in this value gives

\[\begin{aligned} g\left(\frac{2}{e^2-1}\right)&=\left(\frac{2}{e^2-1}\right)^{2}\frac{e^2-1}{2}-2\left(\frac{2}{e^2-1}\right)+\frac{1}{3}\\ &=\left(\frac{4}{(e^2-1)^{2}}\right)\frac{e^2-1}{2}-\frac{4}{e^2-1}+\frac{1}{3}\\ &=\frac{2}{e^2-1}-\frac{4}{e^2-1}+\frac{1}{3}\\ &=-\frac{2}{e^2-1}+\frac{1}{3}\\ &=-\frac{6 + e^{2} + 1}{3(e^2-1)}\\ &= \frac{e^{2}-7}{3(e^{2}-1)}\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
First we solve the integral considering $x$ as a constant:

\begin{align*}
g(x)&=\int_0^1(xe^t-t)^2dt\\
&=\int_0^1(x^2e^{2t}-2xe^tt+t^2)dt\\
&=x^2\int_0^1e^{2t}dt-2x\int_0^1e^ttdt+\int_0^1t^2dt
\end{align*}

The first integral in the sum is

$\int_0^1e^{2t}dt=\frac{1}{2}(e^2-e^0)=\frac{1}{2}(e^2-1)$

Now we solve $\int_0^1e^ttdt$ by parts letting $u=t$ and $dv=e^tdt$ so
that $du=dt$ and $v=e^t$. Hence

\begin{align*}
\int_0^1e^ttdt&=te^t\big|_0^1-\int_0^1e^tdt\\
&=(e-0)-(e-1)=1
\end{align*}

The last integral in the sum is:

$\int_0^1t^2dt=\frac{1}{3}(1^3-0^3)=\frac{1}{3}$

So

$g(x)=\frac{x^2}{2}(e^2-1)-2x+\frac{1}{3}$

The derivative is directly computed to be:

$g'(x)=x(e^2-1)-2$

Which is zero at $x=\frac{2}{e^2-1}$.

To make sure it is a minimum we use the second derivative test. The
second derivative is:

$g''(x)=e^2-1$

Which is always positive (Remember that $e>2$). This means
$x=\frac{2}{e^2-1}$ is the minimum for $g$. Plugging in this value gives

\begin{align*}
g\left(\frac{2}{e^2-1}\right)&=\left(\frac{2}{e^2-1}\right)^{2}\frac{e^2-1}{2}-2\left(\frac{2}{e^2-1}\right)+\frac{1}{3}\\
&=\left(\frac{4}{(e^2-1)^{2}}\right)\frac{e^2-1}{2}-\frac{4}{e^2-1}+\frac{1}{3}\\
&=\frac{2}{e^2-1}-\frac{4}{e^2-1}+\frac{1}{3}\\
&=-\frac{2}{e^2-1}+\frac{1}{3}\\
&=-\frac{6 + e^{2} + 1}{3(e^2-1)}\\
&= \frac{e^{2}-7}{3(e^{2}-1)}
\end{align*}

statement_html: For any real number \(x\), define \(g(x)=\int_0^1(x e^t - t)^2 dt\). Find the minimum value of \(g(x)\).
